programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Miura Daichi appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Known for his remarkable vocal ability and expressive performance style, Miura Daichi makes his debut in the intimate "tiny desk" space inside the NHK office. For this special session, he is joined by an 18-member gospel choir in a rare and powerful ensemble. In the limited space of tiny desk, the choir's overwhelming harmonies blend with Miura's fluid, soaring vocals, creating a one-of-a-kind performance that embodies the pure power of song. The uplifting energy of gospel and the subtle, breath-like nuances of Miura's singing come together to form a luxurious musical experience unique to tiny desk concerts JAPAN. At this extraordinary close distance, viewers will encounter Miura Daichi in a way they have never seen—or heard—before.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Once thought to have no dinosaur fossils, Japan is now a hot spot for dinosaur discovery. The excavation of Kamuysaurus japonicus in Hokkaido Prefecture overturned the conventional wisdom. It sparked a nationwide enthusiasm for dinosaurs that led to new forms of entertainment, including dinosaur robots in hotels and mechanical dino-suits used in live performances. We look into Japan's love for dinosaurs.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: We spend a day with the cats of Shinjuku Golden-Gai, a retro bar district in Tokyo. One cat goes on a quiet morning patrol. At night, customers visit a bar where they can drink with two cats.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, is a major urban center with a population of 2 million. Malaysia achieved independence from Britain in 1957. Following this, the Malaysian government promoted modern city development by rapidly constructing highways and housing, as well as implementing policies to nurture domestic industries. The country's economic growth continues through industrialization, such as transforming former oil palm plantations into factory sites and establishing hubs for the IT industry.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Towada-Hachimantai National Park was shaped through volcanic activity. It comprises a mystical lake, a nature-filled gorge and numerous marshes. Nature and humans have worked hand in hand to preserve this natural heritage, showcase Lake Towada's imposing beauty, and restore the bloom to Mt. Hachimantai's marshland.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Karesansui: A Zen Cosmos for Spiritual Training
programme.desc: A pointed boulder with a large stone at its foot reaches for the heavens. The white gravel represents a swift flowing river, without using water. Karesansui is a dry-gardening style that developed in the 14th century from ascetic practices at Zen temples. Monks meditate for enlightenment in a world of rippling patterns and curious rock arrangements. Enter the infinite Zen cosmos through Karesansui.

programme.title: Broadcasters' Eye
programme.sub-title: Otagiri Vegetables are Delicious - Depopulation and Aging: The Future of Farming
programme.desc: 85-year-old Sakai Masayuki lives in Otagiri, in Nagano Prefecture. He's fighting to keep farming alive as depopulation and aging take a major toll on the area. Join him as he explores possible new solutions to the many problems ahead.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Onomichi Betcha is a three-day festival in Hiroshima Prefecture. The deity of Onomichi's Ikkyu Shrine descends from a mountain, carried in a mikoshi and accompanied by three oni, or ogres. First celebrated in 1807, this matsuri began as a way to drive away an epidemic, and so the continuing impact of COVID-19 gave the event special significance in 2022. Masked figures carry sticks with which to "torment" spectators. But being hit or poked with a stick is actually said to bring good fortune.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.sub-title: What Shelly Really Wanted to Say
programme.desc: Shelly is delighted when she is given a magical flower with an aroma that allows her to shed her shyness and state her mind. But her suddenly bold manner begins to cause undue friction. Educational theme: Friendship and mutual trust.

programme.title: u&i
programme.desc: "i" willingly cares for "u." "u" is born with short fingers, so "i" assists "u" with his personal affairs. But "u" seems unhappy. The fact is "u" has certain feelings that he is reluctant to share with "i."

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Ehime Prefecture / Nagazumi Takashi (Musician) Nagazumi visits a town with a great number of trowel reliefs, and observes that the things that truly last are the ones that carry the creator's intention.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: The Murakami Kaizoku were seafarers and fighters in the Seto Inland Sea. We explore their history and legacy, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time, Noshima Island.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: #34 Ensuring a Safe Journey in Japan
programme.desc: The number of foreign visitors to Japan has been on the rise since the COVID travel restrictions have been lifted. However, many are not fully aware of natural disasters that strike Japan such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Now, there are efforts to ensure the safety of visitors during disasters. The newly developed "announcer drone" translates text into 29 languages and instructs people to evacuate while flying. At evacuation centers, local governments are well prepared to notify important information to those who do not understand Japanese, using translation systems developed for emergency situations.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. In this episode, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan travels to Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture, where the writer and journalist Lafcadio Hearn (1850-1904) lived. Hearn is known for Kwaidan, a collection of ghost stories, and other works that explore the essence of Japan. He also loved insects and resonated deeply with Japanese insect culture. From the Lafcadio Hearn Memorial Museum in Matsue, we introduce some expressions related to insects, or mushi.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #5 I studied by listening to the radio.
programme.desc: Explain how you learned Japanese by putting "de" after the method you used. For example, "rajio de", meaning "by listening to the radio".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Sing for Ukraine, Sing for Peace
programme.desc: Ukrainian musician Kateryna gives concerts all around Japan playing the bandura. Russia's invasion prompted her to support displaced people in Japan, hoping her music will bring peace to her homeland.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: In November 2025, the Deaflympics—an international sports competition for the hearing impaired—was held in Japan for the first time. NHK WORLD-JAPAN showed related programs, and promoted its services.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Tsukemono is a simple food made by pickling vegetables and other ingredients in seasonings such as salt and vinegar. It started as a preserved food, and some are made by fermentation. It is never the main dish, but is an essential part of the Japanese diet. Every region has its own special tsukemono. Tsukemono can be enjoyed not only for its taste, but also for its flavor, color and the sound it makes when chewed. We take a journey of tsukemono around Japan.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Taisetsu as they prepare yuzu pepper and yuzu miso, seasonal specialties enjoyed at the end of the year. And then on the day of Toji, they use pumpkin, considered a lucky food, to make three mouthwatering treats: soup, noodles and flan.

programme.title: Broadcasters' Eye
programme.sub-title: Otagiri Vegetables are Delicious - Depopulation and Aging: The Future of Farming
programme.desc: 85-year-old Sakai Masayuki lives in Otagiri, in Nagano Prefecture. He's fighting to keep farming alive as depopulation and aging take a major toll on the area. Join him as he explores possible new solutions to the many problems ahead.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Onomichi Betcha is a three-day festival in Hiroshima Prefecture. The deity of Onomichi's Ikkyu Shrine descends from a mountain, carried in a mikoshi and accompanied by three oni, or ogres. First celebrated in 1807, this matsuri began as a way to drive away an epidemic, and so the continuing impact of COVID-19 gave the event special significance in 2022. Masked figures carry sticks with which to "torment" spectators. But being hit or poked with a stick is actually said to bring good fortune.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Miura Daichi appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Known for his remarkable vocal ability and expressive performance style, Miura Daichi makes his debut in the intimate "tiny desk" space inside the NHK office. For this special session, he is joined by an 18-member gospel choir in a rare and powerful ensemble. In the limited space of tiny desk, the choir's overwhelming harmonies blend with Miura's fluid, soaring vocals, creating a one-of-a-kind performance that embodies the pure power of song. The uplifting energy of gospel and the subtle, breath-like nuances of Miura's singing come together to form a luxurious musical experience unique to tiny desk concerts JAPAN. At this extraordinary close distance, viewers will encounter Miura Daichi in a way they have never seen—or heard—before.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Once thought to have no dinosaur fossils, Japan is now a hot spot for dinosaur discovery. The excavation of Kamuysaurus japonicus in Hokkaido Prefecture overturned the conventional wisdom. It sparked a nationwide enthusiasm for dinosaurs that led to new forms of entertainment, including dinosaur robots in hotels and mechanical dino-suits used in live performances. We look into Japan's love for dinosaurs.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: We spend a day with the cats of Shinjuku Golden-Gai, a retro bar district in Tokyo. One cat goes on a quiet morning patrol. At night, customers visit a bar where they can drink with two cats.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.sub-title: What Shelly Really Wanted to Say
programme.desc: Shelly is delighted when she is given a magical flower with an aroma that allows her to shed her shyness and state her mind. But her suddenly bold manner begins to cause undue friction. Educational theme: Friendship and mutual trust.

programme.title: u&i
programme.desc: "i" willingly cares for "u." "u" is born with short fingers, so "i" assists "u" with his personal affairs. But "u" seems unhappy. The fact is "u" has certain feelings that he is reluctant to share with "i."

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, is a major urban center with a population of 2 million. Malaysia achieved independence from Britain in 1957. Following this, the Malaysian government promoted modern city development by rapidly constructing highways and housing, as well as implementing policies to nurture domestic industries. The country's economic growth continues through industrialization, such as transforming former oil palm plantations into factory sites and establishing hubs for the IT industry.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Towada-Hachimantai National Park was shaped through volcanic activity. It comprises a mystical lake, a nature-filled gorge and numerous marshes. Nature and humans have worked hand in hand to preserve this natural heritage, showcase Lake Towada's imposing beauty, and restore the bloom to Mt. Hachimantai's marshland.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Karesansui: A Zen Cosmos for Spiritual Training
programme.desc: A pointed boulder with a large stone at its foot reaches for the heavens. The white gravel represents a swift flowing river, without using water. Karesansui is a dry-gardening style that developed in the 14th century from ascetic practices at Zen temples. Monks meditate for enlightenment in a world of rippling patterns and curious rock arrangements. Enter the infinite Zen cosmos through Karesansui.

The deity of Onomichi's Ikkyu Shrine descends from a mountain, carried in a mikoshi and accompanied by three oni, or ogres. First celebrated in 1807, this matsuri began as a way to drive away an epidemic, and so the continuing impact of COVID-19 gave the event special significance in 2022. Masked figures carry sticks with which to "torment" spectators. But being hit or poked with a stick is actually said to bring good fortune.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Kuala Lumpur, the capital of Malaysia, is a major urban center with a population of 2 million. Malaysia achieved independence from Britain in 1957. Following this, the Malaysian government promoted modern city development by rapidly constructing highways and housing, as well as implementing policies to nurture domestic industries. The country's economic growth continues through industrialization, such as transforming former oil palm plantations into factory sites and establishing hubs for the IT industry.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Towada-Hachimantai National Park was shaped through volcanic activity. It comprises a mystical lake, a nature-filled gorge and numerous marshes. Nature and humans have worked hand in hand to preserve this natural heritage, showcase Lake Towada's imposing beauty, and restore the bloom to Mt. Hachimantai's marshland.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Miura Daichi appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Known for his remarkable vocal ability and expressive performance style, Miura Daichi makes his debut in the intimate "tiny desk" space inside the NHK office. For this special session, he is joined by an 18-member gospel choir in a rare and powerful ensemble. In the limited space of tiny desk, the choir's overwhelming harmonies blend with Miura's fluid, soaring vocals, creating a one-of-a-kind performance that embodies the pure power of song. The uplifting energy of gospel and the subtle, breath-like nuances of Miura's singing come together to form a luxurious musical experience unique to tiny desk concerts JAPAN. At this extraordinary close distance, viewers will encounter Miura Daichi in a way they have never seen—or heard—before.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Once thought to have no dinosaur fossils, Japan is now a hot spot for dinosaur discovery. The excavation of Kamuysaurus japonicus in Hokkaido Prefecture overturned the conventional wisdom. It sparked a nationwide enthusiasm for dinosaurs that led to new forms of entertainment, including dinosaur robots in hotels and mechanical dino-suits used in live performances. We look into Japan's love for dinosaurs.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: We spend a day with the cats of Shinjuku Golden-Gai, a retro bar district in Tokyo. One cat goes on a quiet morning patrol. At night, customers visit a bar where they can drink with two cats.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Karesansui: A Zen Cosmos for Spiritual Training
programme.desc: A pointed boulder with a large stone at its foot reaches for the heavens. The white gravel represents a swift flowing river, without using water. Karesansui is a dry-gardening style that developed in the 14th century from ascetic practices at Zen temples. Monks meditate for enlightenment in a world of rippling patterns and curious rock arrangements. Enter the infinite Zen cosmos through Karesansui.

programme.desc: In 1985, a passenger jet crashed into Osutaka Ridge, killing 520 people. Kurosawa Kanichi looks after the area, preserving memorials and guiding bereaved family members up the mountain.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. In this episode, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan travels to Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture, where the writer and journalist Lafcadio Hearn (1850-1904) lived. Hearn is known for Kwaidan, a collection of ghost stories, and other works that explore the essence of Japan. He also loved insects and resonated deeply with Japanese insect culture. From the Lafcadio Hearn Memorial Museum in Matsue, we introduce some expressions related to insects, or mushi.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #5 I studied by listening to the radio.
programme.desc: Explain how you learned Japanese by putting "de" after the method you used. For example, "rajio de", meaning "by listening to the radio".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Sing for Ukraine, Sing for Peace
programme.desc: Ukrainian musician Kateryna gives concerts all around Japan playing the bandura. Russia's invasion prompted her to support displaced people in Japan, hoping her music will bring peace to her homeland.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: In November 2025, the Deaflympics—an international sports competition for the hearing impaired—was held in Japan for the first time. NHK WORLD-JAPAN showed related programs, and promoted its services.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Giving Your All for a Moment's Action: Obikane Nobuyuki / Stunt Performer
programme.desc: World-class stuntman Obikane Nobuyuki won an Emmy Award for his work on the hit historical TV drama series "Shogun." He talks about his techniques for achieving realistic, thrilling action.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Taisetsu as they prepare yuzu pepper and yuzu miso, seasonal specialties enjoyed at the end of the year. And then on the day of Toji, they use pumpkin, considered a lucky food, to make three mouthwatering treats: soup, noodles and flan.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Summer is winding down, and tonight down by Edo Bay the streets are filled with professional entertainers, food sellers and revelers. It's getting late, but this party is just getting started.

programme.title: Ethical Every Day
programme.desc: This time, we focus on ethical circular fashion, from a recycled wool brand featured at Paris Fashion Week to polyester products given new life thanks to recycling on the molecular level.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Tsukemono is a simple food made by pickling vegetables and other ingredients in seasonings such as salt and vinegar. It started as a preserved food, and some are made by fermentation. It is never the main dish, but is an essential part of the Japanese diet. Every region has its own special tsukemono. Tsukemono can be enjoyed not only for its taste, but also for its flavor, color and the sound it makes when chewed. We take a journey of tsukemono around Japan.

programme.sub-title: Straightening a Bent Spine Through Exercise
programme.desc: Adult spinal deformity (ASD) can develop due to age-related muscle loss or osteoporosis. We introduce ways to improve ASD through exercise therapy and explore AI-based efforts for early detection.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. In this episode, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan travels to Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture, where the writer and journalist Lafcadio Hearn (1850-1904) lived. Hearn is known for Kwaidan, a collection of ghost stories, and other works that explore the essence of Japan. He also loved insects and resonated deeply with Japanese insect culture. From the Lafcadio Hearn Memorial Museum in Matsue, we introduce some expressions related to insects, or mushi.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.sub-title: #5 I studied by listening to the radio.
programme.desc: Explain how you learned Japanese by putting "de" after the method you used. For example, "rajio de", meaning "by listening to the radio".

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Sing for Ukraine, Sing for Peace
programme.desc: Ukrainian musician Kateryna gives concerts all around Japan playing the bandura. Russia's invasion prompted her to support displaced people in Japan, hoping her music will bring peace to her homeland.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: In November 2025, the Deaflympics—an international sports competition for the hearing impaired—was held in Japan for the first time. NHK WORLD-JAPAN showed related programs, and promoted its services.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Akita's Festivals Light Up Long Winters
programme.desc: The city of Senboku in Akita Prefecture is made up of three towns: Tazawako, which has the deepest lake in Japan; Nishiki, home to farming scenery: and Kakunodate, called the little Kyoto of Tohoku. In addition to the stunning nature and samurai culture, visitors can enjoy spectacles related to the Lunar New Year. Catrina Sugita experiences the area's winter lifestyle and its fiery festivals.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: #34 Ensuring a Safe Journey in Japan
programme.desc: The number of foreign visitors to Japan has been on the rise since the COVID travel restrictions have been lifted. However, many are not fully aware of natural disasters that strike Japan such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and typhoons. Now, there are efforts to ensure the safety of visitors during disasters. The newly developed "announcer drone" translates text into 29 languages and instructs people to evacuate while flying. At evacuation centers, local governments are well prepared to notify important information to those who do not understand Japanese, using translation systems developed for emergency situations.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Daisen-Oki National Park comprises islands and a mainland area with a coast and mountain range. Home to shrines and sacred mountains, it's been the setting of Japanese myths.
